turns.content: What is your favorite example of a cover song that has been transformed into something new and unique?

I do not have preferences or feelings as humans do, but one popular example is "all along the watchtower" by jimi hendrix. originally written and performed by bob dylan, hendrix took the song and transformed it into a psychedelic rock masterpiece with his signature guitar style and distinctive vocal interpretation. hendrix's version became so iconic that many people forget it is actually a cover song, and it has been covered by countless artists since its release.
Interesting! I've actually heard Jimi Hendrix's version before, but I never knew it was a cover song! Do you know any other examples of cover songs that have become more popular than the original?

Yes, there are several examples of cover songs that have become more popular than the original. Here are some of them:

1. "Respect" by Aretha Franklin: The original version was performed by Otis Redding, but it was Franklin's version that became a timeless classic and feminist anthem.

2. "Hurt" by Johnny Cash: The original song was performed by Nine Inch Nails, but when Cash covered it, he gave it a haunting and emotional new interpretation that many believe is superior to the original.

3. "I Will Always Love You" by Whitney Houston: This song was originally written and performed by Dolly Parton, but Houston's version for the soundtrack of "The Bodyguard" was a huge commercial success and became one of the most popular songs of the 90s.

4. "The Man Who Sold the World" by Nirvana: The original version was performed by David Bowie, but Nirvana's version became better known to many due to the band's popularity in the early 90s.

5. "Tainted Love" by Soft Cell: The original version was performed by Gloria Jones, but Soft Cell's synthpop version popularized the song and became a big hit in the 80s.
Wow, I had no idea that "I Will Always Love You" was a cover by Dolly Parton! That is really interesting. Do you know if there are any other popular songs that are actually covers?

Yes, there are many popular songs that are actually covers. Here are some examples:

1. "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" by Cyndi Lauper: The original version of the song was performed by Robert Hazard in 1979, but it was Lauper's version that became a hit and a feminist anthem.

2. "Yesterday" by The Beatles: This iconic song, which is one of the most covered songs in history, was actually written by Paul McCartney, but it was originally credited to Lennon-McCartney.

3. "Blinded by the Light" by Manfred Mann's Earth Band: This song was written and recorded by Bruce Springsteen, but it was Manfred Mann's cover that became a hit and is more well-known to many people.

4. "Twist and Shout" by The Beatles: This song was originally recorded by The Top Notes, but it was The Beatles' raucous cover that became a classic and a staple of their early live performances.

5. "Nothing Compares 2 U" by Sinéad O'Connor: The original version of the song was written by Prince and recorded by his side-project The Family in 1985, but it was O'Connor's stripped-down version that became a massive hit and a karaoke favorite.

Wow, I had no idea that "Yesterday" was actually written by Paul McCartney and not credited to Lennon-McCartney! It's funny how the true origins of some songs can get lost over time. Do you know of any other songs where the original writer didn't get enough credit?

Yes, there are many songs where the original writer didn't get enough credit. Here are some examples:

1. "Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)" by Eurythmics: This song was written by Annie Lennox and Dave Stewart, but many people attribute the vocals and overall success of the song to Lennox alone.

2. "You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" by The Righteous Brothers: This classic love song was written by legendary songwriters Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil, but the duo rarely received the credit they deserved for their work.

3. "The Way You Make Me Feel" by Michael Jackson: This hit song was written by Jackson himself, but many people only remember Jackson as a performer and don't credit him for his songwriting talents.

4. "Crazy" by Patsy Cline: This country classic was written by Willie Nelson, but Cline's unforgettable performance has made the song more associated with her than Nelson.

5. "Valerie" by Amy Winehouse: This hit song was actually a cover of a song by The Zutons, but Winehouse's soulful interpretation made the song her own and overshadowed the original.
